That's right.

And I bet that you

It's the next version of

So we're going to

We'll talk about new

And we're also going to

Where's the Angular team going.

What other things are

So to tell you all

[APPLAUSE, CHEERS]

DEVIN CHASANOFF:
Thanks, everybody.

What would a
session like this be

without telling developers
about the one thing
they care about most?
That's right.

You guessed it,
integration testing.
I'm kidding.
I'm kidding, new features.

Oh, my God, they
were about to leave.
It's OK, new features.

And we know that building
apps that your users

love goes hand in hand with the
delightful developer experience.

I am just thrilled to
share what the Angular
team has been up to lately.

This team has been on
a roll, just cooking.

And looking back at
all this progress,

I'm convinced that
what I thought

were groundbreaking
features at the time

were really just paving
the way for even more
incredible improvements.

And today, I'm going to
tell you the next part

of the story for Angular
Signals, server-side rendering,

and authoring improvements,
starting with Angular Signals.

When it comes to state
management in Angular,

we've got a new mantra over
here on the Angular team.

Work smarter, not harder,
thanks to Angular Signals.

Last year, we released
signals in developer preview.

At a high level, Signals are
Angular's modern approach

to reactivity, a hassle free way
to manage application state that

reduces the amount of imperative
code that you have to write.

As I like to put it, Angular's
new signal-based approach

takes the management
out of state management,

which I love because when
it comes to writing code,
we're all really lazy.
Wait, who wrote this?
Busy, we're all really busy.
We're not lazy.

A signal is a wrapper around a
value that notifies consumers
when its value has changed.

There are several
variations, including

a signal, your basic
signal, as well as computed.

Now, you might be
asking yourself,

hey, signals have
been around since v17.

Why are you bringing this
up in a talk that was almost

titled all the fantastic updates
coming to Angular developers?

Well, for one,
signal and computed

are now stable, which is a huge
milestone for the framework.

And in v19, we
introduced linked signal.

A linked signal is
a writable signal
dependent on some other state.

Another way to think about
it, in its most basic form,

is a computed signal that
you can set directly.

But linked signal also
gives you the ability

to access prior
state, which makes

it a game changer in
the signal ecosystem,

as I'll illustrate
in just a little bit.

When you factor
in linked signal,

Angular Signals
give you the ability

to create a reactive,
self-managing graph

of your application state,
which means less development

time, means fewer bugs, and
superior maintainability.

This really is a paradigm
shift and a new way of thinking
about state management.

And a large part of
the reason for this,

and I thought this
was so interesting,
signals have no concept of time.
Think about that.

So rather than managing
application state in response

to events that occur over time
and tracking those events,

you design a reactive
system for a computing state
at any given point in time.

It's a subtle but
really important

distinction that you begin
to pick up on the more you
work with signals.

Oh, and did I mention
linked signal is being
upgraded to stable in v20?

Back in V19, we also introduced
a new experimental type

of signal called a
Resource for reactively
fetching asynchronous data.

Or another way to think about
it is a container for data
fetched asynchronously.

And as a reactive primitive,
Resource can update and respond

to other signals
changing value, and it

can notify downstream consumers
when its value has changed.

Let's look at an example
inspired by an app

I built earlier
this year that uses

Gemini to create an interactive,
choose your own adventure
graphic novel builder.

And as a side note, if
you're interested in this,

we open-sourced
the code so you can

go to our angular/examples
GitHub repository
to check it out.
Create your own graphic novels.

And we also live-streamed
us building this live,

alongside our incredible
Angular community.

So you can check out our YouTube
channel if you want to see more.

One of the app's features
is generating images.

Because, well, it wouldn't be a
graphic novel without graphics,
now, would it?

And in addition to
displaying images,

we also wanted to let users
know the loading status

as well as give them the ability
to retry failed requests.

And great news, Resource handles
all of this functionality right
out of the box.
Let's look at some code.
Here we define a Resource.

And it calls an
asynchronous function

to generate an
image using Gemini
through the Genkit library.

Resource has a
params field, which

we've populated with a
signal called imgDescription.

Any time this signal
changes, the Resource

will run the
asynchronous function
defined in our loader field.

The loader function takes
the params as a parameter,

and here, you can see the
loader function uses data

in the params, our
signal, to call

Genkit's asynchronous
runFlow method

to generate an image with
Gemini and return the image URL.

Resource exposes a
status field as well as

this convenient
isLoading method.

So in this case, we can show
a loading spinner to the user
while the request is loading.

And Resource also
has a reload method.

So in the case of
an error, which

is represented by an empty
string in our application,

we can show the user a piece
of UI that, when clicked,
retries the request.

And finally, because the
image resource is effectively

just a container for our
asynchronously fetched data,

we can dynamically set
the image source, thereby
rendering our beautiful image.

And with that, we've created
an entire image generation

pipeline, complete with
loading status, retry,

and we did it all with a single
resource and five lines of code.
That's pretty cool.

And, again, you can see
that we've done this

by defining how application
state will be determined

rather than writing code
that determines it ourselves.

In addition to
generating images,

this app also generates
the story text
for our graphic novel.

Let's look at how we can combine
Resource with linked signal
to accomplish our goal.

This simply wouldn't be

So in this example, we'll make a

is only part of

SSR helps developers

state.

And then once the HTML is

render mode config

APIs to provide greater control

application.

config API to render different

So once you're set up

you can use the
Render Mode field

to declare which
routes should be

pre-rendered at build time

or rendered in the browser

There's even more to

In V19, we also introduced

which is why I've been taking

Stay hydrated, my friends.

So, in case you
need a refresher,

hydration is the
process of restoring

a server-side rendered
application in the client

by doing things like reusing
server-rendered Dom structures,

persisting application
state, and transferring

application data
that was previously
fetched on the server.

Hydration improves
application performance

by avoiding the extra work
to recreate Dom nodes.

With incremental
hydration, you can

leave sections of your
application dehydrated

and incrementally trigger
their hydration as needed.

So this demo here shows
incremental hydration

in action for a
server-side rendered page.

Components that are initially

And at the beginning,

Then you can see the color

In Angular, we handle
this using defer blocks
with hydrate triggers.

As shown in this example, our
large component isn't hydrated

until after a user
interacts with it,

and we can use a placeholder
until that time comes.

This is yet another opportunity
for Angular developers

to improve application
performance by producing smaller

with an experience comparable

But wait, there's more.

This can be extremely
